text:
MARTIN SAVIDGE: This is
the image that has brought
Amelia Earhart back to life.
- This is Amelia Earhart?
- That's right.

MARTIN SAVIDGE: The makers of a
new History Channel documentary

say the tall figure
on the left is Fred
Noonan, Earhart's navigator.

And in the center, sitting
on the dock-- none other
then Earhart herself.

Blurry in the
background, allegedly--
Earhart's plane.

Could this single snapshot
sold an 80-year-old mystery?

In the 1930s, Amelia
Earhart was a superstar.

She was an aviation pioneer
recognized around the world--

a role model who
disappeared without

a trace attempting the
greatest triumph of her life--

to become the first woman
to circle the globe.

She and Noonan were flying
by way of the Equator.

And they'd made
it 3/4 of the way

when they disappeared July
2, 1937 over the Pacific.

Despite the largest search
effort in US history
at the time, nothing was found.

DOROTHY COCHRANE:
We believe that she
ditched into the Pacific Ocean.

MARTIN SAVIDGE: This new photo
was found in the National

Archives and is said to be of
Jaluit Atoll in the Marshall
Islands, but there's no date.

To some, it supports
the controversial theory

that Earhart and Noonan
crashed and were taken
prisoner by the Japanese--

it was, after all, just
before World War II--

and that the pair were
executed or died in prison.

Dorothy Cochrane at
the Smithsonian Air
and Space Museum is skeptical.

DOROTHY COCHRANE: We
have no evidence of that.

The Japanese government
has said that it's untrue.

MARTIN SAVIDGE: What do
you think of this new photo
that's been brought to light?
RIC GILLESPIE: Not much.

I'm surprised that it's gotten
as much attention that it has.

MARTIN SAVIDGE: Ric Gillespie
and his aviation group

have been looking for
Earhart since the 1980s.

And they've made more than
a dozen trips to the region.

He believes he died as a
castaway, not as a prisoner.

RIC GILLESPIE: If
this is a picture

of Amelia Earhart
in Japanese custody,
where are the Japanese?
There are no soldiers there.
There's nobody in uniform.
There's nobody with a weapon.

There's nobody that's
guarding anybody.

MARTIN SAVIDGE: Still,
both understand the buzz.

DOROTHY COCHRANE:
It's fascinating

when one of the most
famous people in the world
simply disappears.

MARTIN SAVIDGE:
Though it may not

solve aviation's
greatest mystery,
the photo does prove something--

80 years later, Amelia
Earhart-- the pilot,
the pioneer, the role model--
is also still a superstar.
Martin Savidge, CNN.
